reviewText:
The real magic of going through your gaming backlog is stumbling across those little gems you didn't know you had.

Such was the case with Shank. I'm not sure when I purchased it, but there it was sitting in my library covered in e-dust. I watched the trailer, and it gave me a feint reminder of Mark of the Ninja. I was intrigued.

So I sat down to play it, and a short weekend later I was done. I laid witness to great storytelling, a beautiful aesthetic, and gameplay that, while just a beat-em-up, was deep enough to leave me feeling completely satisfied.

The one thing that stood above the rest would definitely be the music. It goes to great lengths to set a moody atmosphere that feels ripped right out of a Tarantino or Robert Rodriguez movie. In fact, if you've seen El Mariachi or Pulp Fiction you'll know roughly what you're getting in to.

If you're bored and looking for something to do, puchase and play this game. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
KNIFE to meet you! - Annoymous

THE GOOD
Shank controls nicely on the gamepad (Which is what the devs want you to play this on) and feel better than the PC controls, although Shank is a spam fest either way. Button-mashing is inevitable and gameplay is repetative as the same enemies will attack you in the same ways. I never said that it wasn't fun though, as Shank pulls it off with such style that I really cannot find the gameplay boring. Sure the enemies will take a long time to kill and you will take some damage in the process but it's fair and will drop you health and extra weapons for your troubles.

THE GREAT
Graphically I cannot find fault with Shank's aesthetic. The character animations are smooth, the character models are functional, the backgrounds (Silhouettes) do thier job and the scenery looks pleasing at the very least. Shank seems to break up the fighting from time to time by adding in puzzle sections which flows nicely and gives players hands a rest from the constant button-mashing. Mechanics of Shank are fairly simple with not too much getting in the way of redecorating the walls with enemies intestines, and on the topic of intestines it feels like the devolpers wanted this to be more violent in parts. I expected some gruesome deaths from enemies once I got a high enough combo which makes you feel that this game is censored. We'll get to that later.

THE UGLY
It's later. The story is absolutely terrible and it seems that the main character, appropriately named Shank is just out to kill the Big Bad because he doesn't lke him. I played the Steam version through to the second boss fight and then downloaded the Humble Bundle 4 version (Which I got a while ago) and noticed that the cutscenes had been changed to the point where the story makes no sense. I cannot understand why Steam would censor an M rated game, but I'm not complaining. The only other real issue is the fact that this game was made for the gamepad. It says so on the intro screen and shows it by having the default controls worse than my home country's rating system. These are two seemingly petty gripes but they really ruin the experince.

THE VERDICT
Do you see how I've recommended this game? I've recommended it on two conditions. These follow:
1- You own a gamepad as the default and customizable controls are terrible
2- You don't care about the story/you watch the cutscenes through YouTube to grasp the story/you'll played this game on console and know the story
These are the only conditions I would recommend Shank and that's a real shame because I like Shank, I possibly even love Shank, but if I'm being honest then that's my recommendation to you.

reviewText:
I would love to love this game. It has a fantastic presentation with a Mexican desert flavor, great animation, big boss fights, a plethora of different looking enemies and it is a 2D beat em up published EA (but people think its indie). Its just not fun. In an era full of Metroidvanias beat em ups such as Guacamelee, you will find Shank is more of a basic left to right sidescroller with very few ups and downs. There are no secret areas or even breakable walls with meat in them. If the original Castlevania had secrets, why not Shank?

The game has great controls, a quick melee button, strong melee button, a gun attack, a pounce button, grapple button, grenade button, block button and even a jump. It has everything that you'd ever want in a 2D beat em up. With all of that being said, it feels so monotonous. Your attacks feel very weak and each enemy takes an exorbitant amount of hits. The enemies are pretty smart, they'll block and roll through you to sandwich you between enemies. If they have enough distance, they'll pull a gun out and shoot. While there are a lot of different looking enemies, they all pretty much fall into a few categories. Standard foot soldiers, big brawlers, weapon users and dogs.

The game is very forgiving on normal mode. There are no lives, you just respawn pretty close to where you died. It is a welcome decision to do so. Of course, there is a hard mode too.

The problem with the game is that it gets dull really quick especially when you have the same attacks from start to finish. You gain no new abilities to keep things fresh. There are a few extra guns and strong melee weapons that you can use, but nothing feels like an upgrade, just a sidegrade. The bosses boil down to finding a weakness to exploit, pouncing on them and stabbing them.

There are light traversals to break up combat for a mere two seconds, such as climbing a brief fall, briefly hanging from a pipe or jumping platform to platform, but it just needed more of a break from the monotony of combat. It is so odd that there can be so much diversity in combat, and yet you can still just button mash your way to victory. Also what does it say about Shank's combat when the next game the creators made after Shank 2 was a stealth game? Another issue with the game is the blah music.

There is co-op to improve the experience, but having a friend around can improve any experience. I'm from an era of Nintendo and Super Nintendo beat em ups that have less combat options, but more enemy diversity. I just couldn't get into Shank.

Finally, there will be plenty of sales if not game bundles with Shank 1 and 2. Just wait for the combo pack sales with $5 for both.

reviewText:
When I started playing Shank I'd been already familiar with Klei Entertainment - their game, Mark of The Ninja, is one of my favourites and it is among those where I have 100% achievement completion. Of course, MoTN only came out 2 years later, therefore, I expected Shank would have its shortcomings.

Now, Shank is a fast-paced, action-packed side-scroller that reminds us of the good-old beat 'em up games from the arcade era. We proceed from one screen to the other while getting rid of dozens of enemies and eventually coming to a boss battle. At our disposal we have melee weapons (chainsaw!) and some firearms. While nothing fancy, making combos with all of our available items is pretty cool in the heat of battle especially when enemies are pouring in from every which way!

The game has cutscenes between the levels and a great accompanying soundtrack. While short (can be completed in a couple of hours), for hardcore gamers the hard mode is available offering an extra challenge by completely removing the checkpoints.

There are 2 things that make Shank stand out. First, we immediately notice that the game has a comic book art style - this was later used to make MoTN happen and Shank also has a sequel with similar graphics style. Now, the 2nd and perhaps most interesting is the excessive gore / violence the game uses.

I found it a bit too much at times - I admit this is the game's style but even the cutscenes have some pretty gory scenes for no apparent reason. I understand the game later on underwent an upgrade and as a result of that some of the more violent scenes were removed / edited including some nudity.

Don't go looking for a story here as you do not really have one. This is Shank's tale of revenge against his previous employer but it really is just a basis for killing a whole bunch of enemies (they never really elaborate on the story). This is not necessarily a problem as you are here for the chainsaw! :)

To summarise: Shank is a decent beat 'em up from Klei Entertainment which offers a couple of hours of entertainment if you do not really have any other game at your disposal. I look forward to completing its sequel! This is an easy pick-up - especially when discounted - just remember to use a controller!

A very pretty game but not a very fun one. Thankfully it's short.

reviewText:
Shank is a great side scrolling beat em' up game, much like the olden days of Double Dragon, Final Fight or Streets of Rage except no 3rd dimension.

The game is over the top violent, which makes it oh so wonderful.  I found myself mashing buttons together just to see what crazy combo he would pull off next.  Some but not all of the environments are interactive, for example while on a train you can throw bad guys off of it.  I found that incredibly entertaining.

The game is a side scroller which means at some point you're going to have to jump through obstacle courses.  The developers did this step right though, for instance if you're sliding down a slope and you need to make a life or death decision in the next few seconds, the game will go into slow motion until you make that decision.  It's an excellent system, but this feature goes away in the final levels, which is a bummer because then you have to memorize the next few steps, or die and restart from the last checkpoint.

Boss battles are actually fun, as each one has a tick, similiar to Punchout, and no two boss battles are the same.

Overall a very good game that deserves a play through if you enjoy side scrolling beat em' ups.

reviewText:
Very good brawler. Tight controls, interesting moves, decent weapon variety, and a nice artstyle. I personally found it enjoyably challenging, and a bit frustrating at times even on Normal difficulty, but I'm not really much of a fighter/brawler player so your experience may vary. The story was somewhat interesting but truth be told it was nothing revolutionary imo.

It's not without flaws, of course. Enemy variety is frankly not the most impressive. Also be warned the singleplayer story mode is very short. First playthrough only took me about 2 to 3 hours. There's some replayability if you want to try hard mode or unlock all the costumes, but frankly after you settle into a pattern of attack that you like, beating up very similar goons already becomes somewhat repetitive in the first playthrough so I'm not sure how many more I'd be interested in doing. There's a multiplayer campaign I haven't done yet, so maybe there's some meat to be had there.

Also the save system is automatic and stage based, and it's not always completely clear what the stage start and end points are. So if like me you decide you want a break after reaching a checkpoint and exit the game, you might find yourself having to repeat some content.

Around 2 hours of my play time were actually alt-tabbed because I was getting a bit salty and wanted a break, but didn't want to redo the whole stage thanks to the limited autosave system.

It was an enjoyable experience and I would recommend it, just be aware that this can indeed be a game you beat in one (short) sitting.

reviewText:
Shank is a very violent hand drawn 2D sideways scrolling beat/shoot 'em up.

The presentation is excellent - badass gory comic book style cutscenes, great sound effects, and a really fitting gritty soundtrack. The story itself is a very shallow revenge plot, but I couldn't care less - it sets the mood perfectly.

Good combat mechanics - 4 weapon categories: The mandatory melee weapon (Two knives), heavy melee weapon (machete, chain saw etc), ranged weapon (guns etc), and grenades (frag, mines, molotovs).  I did find the gravity a bit too weak though - it all felt a wee bit too floaty for my taste.

There's a good variation in enemy types and a boss in the end of each level, so even though you could argue the combat is fairly simple, I still found it varied, challenging and rewarding enough to keep me entertained for the 3 hours of gameplay the campaign provides. There's also a co-op campaign.

The gameplay using an xbox360 controller didn't feel quite as tight as I had hoped for. While the analouge stick is good for aiming the ranged weapon, it felt a bit too indirect/unresponsive for character control.

Generally it's pretty evident that it's a console port, as e.g. the devs didn't even bother hiding the mouse cursor during gameplay.

I bought Shank1+2 at 75% off, and at that price it's just ridiculously high value for money, but even at full price it's a recommended purchase for fans of the genre.

reviewText:
In this genre of games, I think the masterpiece still stands as Final Fight. So I will mostly compare this with Final Fight.

- The art greatly surpasses Final Fight, but it's not a direct result of 20 odd years that passed between these two games. Shank tries to establish its own style that has been a good mix of Metal Slug, Western and Tarantino movies and executes it near flawlessly. The game's greatest merit is its art to be honest.

- Lack of ridiculous ♥♥♥♥ to do or secret locations. There aren't any of them unlike Final Fight where you beat a car for no good reason but still a good amount of fun and something to achieve and try to set a record on. Compared to Guacamalee, lack of secret locations also can be more noteworthy.

- Comparing stories, Shank and Final Fight both follow a cliche story about a woman but Shank does it a lot better and the story has a good amount of Robert Rodriguez vibe, which I found incredibly done. Also the characters are fleshed out a lot more, unlike Final Fight's bosses.

- When it comes to gameplay, Final Fight was much more superior. All of your combos made sense and were devoid of button mashing. Also Final Fight tried to keep combos and attack moves a lot simpler but timing of them and the strategy used to defeat a number of enemies in an area mattered much more than button mashing.

- Final Fight allowed you to trap your enemies to a corner of the screen and beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of them, which made the game a lot easier than it could have been if you couldn't exploit this. Shank carries this trope to some extent, you will mostly be able to corner your enemies and beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of them except for bosses and some enemy types.

- Some fights consists of throwing multiple waves of heavy enemies at you without having a chance to rest or save and it's pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Yes, the game scenario makes sense for you to fight them, but having a 8-10 minutes of constant fighting and starting all over when beaten just feels unfair to me.

- Responsiveness of the controls are sometimes ♥♥♥♥ed, which was purely perfect for Final Fight. I often wondered why my fighter insisted on shooting at the opposite direction or failed to grab one item in multiple tries. When it comes to dodging, controls ♥♥♥♥ up more and you find yourself standing in the middle of 5 large enemies.

- I won't be able to compare this with Final Fight due to era's technical limitations but compared to Guacamalee the amount of gore in the game is just lovely and it is very satisfying to violently strangle someone with chains or how you behead bosses.

All in all, if you're interested in the genre or want something interesting, Shank can be a good choice when on sale and fortunately it goes on sale very frequently.

reviewText: Take everything I say about Shank with a big ol’ spoonful of salt; I don’t like platformers, I generally don’t like 2D side scrolling, and I hate brawlers and fighting games. So what is Shank? It is a 2D side scrolling brawler with comic book aesthetics and short elements of reactionary platforming.\nNeedless to say I started off the first level with a sour taste in my mouth and my judgments pre-rendered. After all of that, I’m not going to make a 180 and say Shank is great, but I got WAY more enjoyment out of it than I ever expected. The fighting felt to me like a run-and-gun adaptation of the combat found in Mark of the Ninja (a game I actually am quite fond of). While the platforming certainly picked at my nerves, the sections were short enough that I was able to push through them and keep playing. Helping matters was that Shank is an absolutely gorgeous game from an aesthetic standpoint. The animations are clear and well fleshed out, the cut-scenes are very rich and capture that comic book vibe, and the colors - while a bit muted for my tastes - are varied from level to level.\nIn the end, Shank is still a brawler. I don’t like memorizing combos and I don’t like how any fighting games handle. But I think in the end, that just says a lot for the quality that this game brings to the table. I’m not about to hand out my game of the year award, but Shank is pretty alright.

reviewText:
Your girl has been slain by those you once called comrades, and now, one by one, you will have your revenge. Sweet, bloody revenge. All of this, of course, is just an excellent excuse for some clever, enjoyable platforming and delightful strategic combat.

There's something fascinating about charging at a thug with your chainsaw drawn, and flicking him into the air with a satisfying growl of its engine, then juggling his body with a blast from your shotgun. And because you are driven by REVENGE, then leaping into the air and manifesting your titular shanks into his prone body, before hurling him into the crowd.

As Shank continues on his vengeful quest, he adds machetes, katanas, machine guns, and much more to his arsenal. For, if nothing else, Shank is multi-talented.

And then there's co-op mode, where Shank's good friend joins him on his quest for revenge. I don't recall what his name is -- I just always call him Danny Trejo.  So there you go.  You can play as Danny Trejo.

Classic side scrolling beat 'em up with very good visuals and animations, good combat mechanics and shallow storyline. What's not to like? Made by my very favourite Klei Entertainment, the game is very stylish and straightforward - exactly what I would expect from a beat 'em up.

The ~5 hours of gameplay are just enough for you to finish the game without getting bored with repetitive battles. Although I never get tired of chainsaw butcheries.

On the negative side of things - there were some unpleasant bugs in the Mac version that made the game unplayable from time to time.

What's it about?
Shank is a side-scrolling brawler by Klei Entertainment, who also brought you such titles as Don't Starve and Mark of the Ninja. Playing as the titular protagonist, you make your way through several levels, slaughtering dozens of thugs and hired goons along the way on a one-man quest for revenge.

How does it play?
The undeniable strength of Shank is its combat. Within the first few minutes of the game, you'll be stringing together devastating combos utilising the weapons at your disposal. You have a light attack, a heavy attack and a firearm attack, and your heavy weapon and firearm can be swapped on the fly with weapons you pick up throughout the game. The fighting has a wonderful feeling of weight and impact to it, and hacking down the beautifully animated enemies is an absolute delight. The bosses are unusual and enjoyable to fight, though most can be beaten in more or less the same way. There is some rudimentary platforming involved in traversing the levels, which doesn't get in the way of the action too much.

Because the game was designed for console, it is highly recommended that you use a controller to play it. Trying to play with the keyboard will turn out to be an altogether fiddly and unenjoyable experience, since the buttons you need will be all over the place. Shank uses almost every button and directional input on the controller, and that amounts to 16 keys on the keyboard. Another bugbear is that levels often involve hazards and enemy placements that can lead to unfair deaths and frustration; the church level in particular, with its falling missiles, can be a nightmare to get through. There is also an odd glitch with the chainsaw's jumping attack in which you and your target can become stuck if you try to jump before the attack animation is finished, forcing you to reload the last checkpoint. It is also not a very long game; I finished it in less than three hours, so take that into consideration before purchasing.

How does it look?
In a word, gorgeous. Keli have a knack for nailing their art styles, and Shank is no exception. The character sprites are beautifully designed and animated, and serve to make the already great combat look and feel even better. The environments are equally gorgeous, though there are points at which elements in the foreground appear onscreen and obscure parts of the stage. This often happens in areas with enemies, which can prove annoying when you are fighting or being attacked in a place you can't see. Despite this little problem, the graphics are delightful to look at, and the resolution options mean you shouldn't have a problem getting it to run on your system.

How does it sound?
Perhaps less impressive out of all of this is the sound design. The music mostly consists of loops of Mexican standoff-style tunes that fit the game very well, but can get a little repetitive after a while. The enemy shouts and grunts also get very samey (and for some reason, Shank's death rattle sounds almost identical to the Heavy from TF2). The various slashing and shooting sounds are well done, and the chainsaw in particular sounds like the industrial death machine it should. The voice acting in the cutscenes could have been better, but then again, the story is not what's important here.

Long story short
Shank is a brutal, bloody and highly entertaining beat-'em-up from a highly talented indie studio. The combat is some of the best I've experienced in a 2D game, and the art style is both beautiful to look at and serves to add to the combat experience. A few problems here and there, but Shank is a game that is definitely worth your time and money.

Good Points
Outstanding combat system
Gorgeous visuals
Interesting environments and bosses
Bad Points
The occasional game-breaking glitch
Sound design could have been better
Some questionable decisions in level and art design
May be too short for some

reviewText:
While I recommend this game it does have some glaring flaws that really bothered me.

The good: the gameplay is pretty sweet.  It's just well designed and I liked the mechanics a lot.  It's reminiscent of old 2d beat em ups, or to a lesser extent Devil May Cry.  Story is, well, it's alright.  You're not really here for story time, though.  I very much enjoyed the animation style.

The most glaring flaw is that regular enemies just have way too many hit points.  Killing normal enemies is an absolute grind, and it takes so damned long.  It isn't fun to beat up on the same 3 or 4 dudes for a couple of minutes at a time.  The gameplay really feels like you should be plowing through these guys, and while that's what I wanted, it most certainly isn't what happens.  However, if you go into the game knowing this, it probably won't bother you as much as it did me.  I just hated sitting in fights wondering how much longer it would take.

Although the bosses are colorful they can also be sort of frustrating.  For the most part the game demands that you figure out a special trick/tell to each boss and doing that isn't really easy.   Personally I don't think that the tells to what you need to do are obvious enough.  Example: I don't know what the hell I was supposed to do against the final boss, I ended up just brute forcing him because I couldn't figure it out.  It's possible to brute force the guys down, sure, but it takes much, much longer, which isn't viable in a game like this because of your limited healthbar.

I didn't have a bad time with Shank.  It's an alright game, not great, not bad.  Could have been a lot better, but that really isn't saying anything.

reviewText:
Slick, varied and downright fun combat is really all this game is about. Sure, it has an attractive art style and an enjoyable (if somewhat cliché) soundtrack but its core is the 2D beat-em-up gameplay. Be sure you have a controller you can play with as I can't imagine playing this with the keyboard (I used a PS2 controller).

For me, the highlight of Shank is its boss fights. Each one has a unique weakness that you can take advantage of. However, if you want more of a challenge or can't figure out the weakness, you have the option to whittle them down with normal attacks. While there isn't a huge variety in the grunts that you'll fight, I never grew tired of them because you steadily unlock new weapons that reinvigorate things and quite simply, the game isn't long enough to start getting bored. It also helps that you have 6 different attacks, a dodge/block button and jumping at your disposal as you combo your way to victory. There are some platforming bits that got tiring but fortunately the developers were smart enough to keep those sections short.

The story is a very simple tale of revenge that is entirely forgettable but serves its purpose to drive the action forward. The voice acting is equally adequate without being distractingly bad nor anything noteworthy.

Given Shank's short length it's hard to recommend at full price. But on sale or packaged in something like a Humble Bundle it will surely entertain you for an afternoon or two.

reviewText: As the game loads each time, you are instantly presented with a warning that you should be using a controller to play the game. This is unacceptable, as I've purchased it for PC, and I expect it to be played as such. Despite this misplaced excuse of a warning, Shank can be played and enjoyed with the keyboard. The controls and combinations aren't too pitiful, and you will be able to execute most of them as soon as you get used to how the mechanics work. The artwork is well done, in a comic book style setting. The voice acting is okay for what it is, but you should not expect them to be excellent. Even though the game is violent, the overall atmosphere is quite mild and cartoony. The story isn't very original nor is it interesting, but it does fit fine with the overall presentation and game play style. Even though Shank attempts to go back to the glory days of early to mid 90s Beat 'em ups, it comes off as unpolished and sometimes inadequate in some forced platforming elements. There is very little variety between the levels and enemies, and once you get acquainted with the moves, Shank gets increasingly repetitive in all aspects, and you will be hoping for a quick finish to the game. After a very short while, it all looks the same, feels the same, and plays the same. The unlocks don't add much at all, and there is very little to be gained with the weapons the game makes available to the player on a permanent basis as you progress through the story. The boss battles can often drag and do not offer any true challenge or difference in game play in comparison to the rest of the enemies. There is very little charm in Shank, in comparison to games of the same genre from earlier generations. It's button mashing without any skill or strategy whatsoever. The music and setting are akin to stereotypical Southwestern United States, and this provides the player with slight immersion to the theme, albeit a basic one. The general concept would have been better suited for a short animated film instead of a shallow and slightly subpar game. Tedious fight mechanics coupled with poorly designed boss battles makes for a forgettable and passable gaming experience.\n\nShank is okay.

reviewText: Shank is a pretty nice 2D side-scrolling brawler video game which could have been made for 80s or 90s coin-operated arcade machines. It was developed in comic book art graphic convention mixed with Quentin Tarantino and Robert Rodriguez style as well as great sound effects and appropriately feisty soundtrack. This game features plenty of enemies to be brutally exterminated with heavy melee weapons like chainsaw, some firearms and grenades. I really like cool and simple combat system in this production (attacking, dodging and combos) but, unfortunately, there are moments too easy for old school players like me when you need to jump out from one place to another (and parts with climbing or slipping etc.). Furthermore, Shank is an awfully short game. It is good that several challenges are quite difficult and you are also able to increase the difficulty level by selecting hard-core mode. A nice addition is simple a little bit stupid plot with a grain of salt and some dark sense of humor with plenty occasions to shed blood.

The game pays homage to the Double Dragon/Streets of Rage style of gameplay, but ramps it up a notch to awesome.  This a solid beat-em-up with a variety of weapons at your disposal. I find the handling to be a bit sticky, not as accurate as I would expect from the genre, especially with the wide range of moves at your disposal.  For example I would pounce on a person and start beating the hell out of them and while I'm on top of them I will either aim left or right and shoot to take out others nearby, but I have to be extra deliberate with the button presses for him not to shoot in the wrong direction.  The same could be said for dodging, juggling, and shooting up or down.  I hear they totally revamped the controls for the second and that fact alone is enough to drive me to play the sequel.

I'm going to be honest: I didn't expect to enjoy Shank.
However, Shank is now one of my favorite games, and is a a game I recommend to any friend with a few spare bucks.
Shank is a 2D sidescroller with wonderful comic-book style graphics, an amazingly satisfying combat system, and unique parkour mechanics.
The combat system is stunning.You have three weapons at any given time: your heavy weapon, your gun, and your shanks. You can switch out each of these on the fly (there are 4 heavy weapons and 3 guns), though they have to be unlocked progressively. The game gives you new weapons seemingly the MOMENT you get used to the previous ones. Combat is ridiculously fast paced: the game constantly throws enemies at you, and you have to block, pounce, shoot, stab, and slice through your opponents at light-speed.
Movement is equally well done: you can run up (nearly) any wall by climbing with your shanks, you can swing off of lamp posts and other hanging objects, you can slide down inclines, and other parkour game staples. Seeing this in a 2D space may seem like a horrible idea, but trust me, it's great.
The story is kind of cliche, but it's seriously unpredictable. You really don't understand what's going on until halfway through the game, as the backstory is slowly revealed through flashbacks, and the final flashback isn't until the final stage of the final boss of the final level.
In short: it's a Mexican drug cartel action-romance-tragedy-mystery.
Shank also includes a separate local co-op campaign and controller support (in fact, the game works better on a controller.)
If you have 10 dollars to spare, or want to play a 2D game, or just want a hell of a good time, pick up Shank.

reviewText: Got Shank for the free weekend. Played Shank for 10 or 15 minutes. Went and bought Shank. Wrote a review. It's an amazing game, fun as hell, complete with the perfect amount of over the top and Klei's beautiful art style. It'd just be a shame to pass up the amazing deal that's being offered, but I'd easily buy this game at full price.

DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine
Shank is the first game in the Shank franchise by Klei Entertainment, the wonderful people behind Mark of the Ninja. Shank and its sister sequel Shank 2 were developed before Mark of the Ninja and does not focus on straight stealth like Mark of the Ninja did, but full on action with the same art style and same bloody action

The story basically shows us a guy named Shank who was tasked in killing his wife but was followed by some other gang members of Cesar where they kill his wife and leave him left for dead, this storyline made me say that it is something roughly around Quentin Tarantino's Kill Bill volumes (which I highly recommend watching!)

The game is exteremly short, homing in at around 3 hours. But it does have its good and bad sides. Bad, because it is extremly short but good because it does get repetitive after a while. Shank 2 apparently suffers with the same length problems homing in at around 4 hours long (checked via howlongtobeat.com), thankfully Shank does offer a New Game+ mode as well as a multiplayer campaign... but sadly, I don't have any friends to try it out :(

The graphics are beautiful and made me remember playing Mark of the Ninja (I played Mark of the Ninja before Shank) as well as Disney cartoons, only Disney's cartoons are less bloody than Shank is. The animations are also really good, from the sword play to the gun fighting

The controls are very annoying on PC and it shows that Shank was originally developed for Xbox and then horribly ported onto the PC, it is impossible to play it on a keyboard, so much so that I had to plug in my controller to play it properly, and if you do happen to have a controller, I highly recommend playing with it as soon as you start. No wonder the game highly recommends playing with a controller when you boot up the game, it wasn't joking...

The music and sound effects, are okay but nothing memorable

You will die, a lot, thankfully there is a fair checkpoint system in the game. The voice acting was okay but nothing special, it does suffer like Mark of the Ninja's voice acting, some good, some bad...

I had fun playing Shank, even though it did have its fair share of problems here and there, but on the whole, it was a really good action game. Hopefully, its sequel would have ironed out most of the problems Shank had... hopefully...

Shank doesn't necessarily start off on a journey to find answers as much as finding every goon and thug related to the Cesar and stab, slice, decaptitate, and most notably what he does best, ... shank each one of them.

When his boss leaves him for dead, Shank must kill everyone who stands in his way to get revenge.  With his trusty chainsaw, pistols, and shank, he sets out on a bloody journey.

This sidescrolling beat-em-up is exactly what fans of the genre expect.  Tight controls with numerous and varied weapons that have their own strengths and weaknesses, dozens of enemy types, beautiful comic-style graphics, and a storyline even Quentin Tarantino could appreciate make this a game to pay attention to.

Shank’s bloodthirsty rampage will take him across about a half-dozen vaguely Latin-inspired stages, each with their own visual flair and memorable boss battles.  New weapons are gifted frequently, and you’ll enjoy learning how to string them together into absurdly long combo attacks against the seemingly never-ending waves of enemies.  Given the quality of the art and design, it isn’t too much of a negative to say this game is quite short: I beat the whole thing in under three hours.

There is a co-op campaign that details the backstory of Shank’s initial betrayal and how he ended up in this mess in the first place.  Yes, a co-op campaign that is actually separate from the main story, but still impacts it!  More games should take that approach.  It is only available in local mode, so you’ll need a real life in-person friend to play it.

The graphics are absolutely gorgeous.  Crisp, clean and excellently drawn characters make every boss fight memorable.  The waves and waves of enemies in between them also look good, and every single enemy is animated in their own unique way.  The music is likewise extremely well done, adding another welcome layer of drama to the mix.

Klei Entertainment nailed it with this one.  I have a few minor quibbles with it, like the fact that some enemies attacks are telegraphed way too late for you to be able to react to them, but overall it is excellently made.  This is a great way to spend an afternoon or two, getting revenge for lost love by way of chainsaw and shotgun.
